issues.description: Constructor/attribute mismatch for Animal: The UML in the problem statement declares Animal with two attributes (name: String and age: int) and a constructor Animal(String, int), but the provided example code (template Main) and the solution implementation use single-argument constructors (e.g., new Seal("Clarabelle")) and the solution's Animal class only defines a name attribute and a single-parameter constructor (Animal(String)). This is an internal contradiction in the specification vs. the code and will confuse students whether they must implement an age field and a two-parameter constructor or follow the one-parameter design shown in the template/example.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the specification and starter code consistent. Either (A) update the problem statement/UML to remove the age attribute and specify Animal(String) as the constructor (and adjust UML to show only name: String and constructor Animal(String)), or (B) update the template and solution so Animal has both name: String and age: int, implement a constructor Animal(String, int), and change all example instantiations (Main and the concrete animal constructors) to pass an age argument. Choose one approach and align UML, instructions, template Main, and solution accordingly so students are not blocked by conflicting constructor/attribute requirements.

issues.description: The UML in the problem statement declares Animal with a constructor signature Animal(String, int) and lists an age attribute, while the provided template/solution use single-argument constructors for Animal/subclasses (e.g., Seal("Clarabelle")) and the solution's Animal class only has a single String name attribute and a constructor Animal(String). This mismatch between the problem UML and the code can confuse students about the expected attributes and constructor parameters for Animal and its subclasses (should they provide an age when constructing animals?).
issues.suggested_fix: Make the constructor/attribute specification consistent across artifacts. Either (A) update the problem statement UML to show Animal(String) (remove age) so it matches the template and solution, or (B) add the age attribute and a two-argument constructor Animal(String, int) to the template and solution (and update all subclass constructors and Main usage accordingly). Prefer option (A) if age is not required for the exercises; otherwise choose (B) and propagate the change to all example usages.
